SENT.plain: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE: Silent brain infarctions (SBI) are common findings in advanced age, but their relationship to dementia is still uncertain
The present study was designed to evaluate whether SBI predict the development of dementia after first clinical ischemic stroke
METHODS: We blindly studied admission CT scans of 175 consecutive nondemented patients presenting with ischemic stroke that clinically was their first stroke episode
SBI were defined as CT evidence of infarcts not compatible with the acute event
The patients were subsequently followed for their mental state for 5 years
Survival analysis, wherein onset of dementia was the end point, was performed on the total sample population and conducted separately on those with and without SBI at admission
RESULTS: Dementia developed in 56 patients (32%), including 22 of the 63 (35%) with SBI and 34 of the 112 (30%) without SBI
Thus, dementia was not related to SBI
CONCLUSIONS: Our data indicate that SBI do not predict the development of dementia after stroke
